The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs "informed the Cabinet that if there was to be another Meeting before Tuesday next he would not raise any question of Fereign Affairs at thepresent Meeting. If not, he would be obliged todo so.The Acting Psime Minister informed the Cabinetthat he had received a telegram from the PrimeMinister asking if he could meet as many of hiscolleagues as would be available at 2-30 p.law onFRIDAY NEXT, NOVEMBER 1st.The Cabinet agreed -(a) To meet at 10, Downing Street, onFriday, November 1st, at 2-30 p.m.(b) That as many members of the cabinet who could arrange to do so shouldbe on the platform at Euston Stationon Friday to meet the Prime Minister.(c) That the Secretary should make arrangements, through the appropriatechannels, in regard"to Police arrange-ments at Euston for the convenience ofMinisters and for notifying ministers of the exact time of the Prime Minister'arrival.(NOTE: The Secretary has arranged withMr Usher, one of the PrimeMinister's Private Secretariesat 10, Downing Street, to notifymembers of the Cabinet on Fridaymorning as to the exact time atwhich the Prime Minister's trainis due, and to make the necessary arrangements with Scotland Yard.)fPHS PRIMEMINISTER' return. we britishooal industry.(previous reference:Cabinet 38(29), Con-elusion 1.)2. The Cabinet had before them a Note by theLord Privy Seal (Paper C.P.-292 (29)) circulatingthe following documents for the consideration ofthe Cabinet:-(i) A letter from Mr A. J. Cook, dated october 29th, and a draft reply which the Committee on the CoalIndustry recommend should be sent.(ii) The draft "Proposals in regard tothe Coal Industry under discussion between the Government, the mining association and the Miners'Federation? to be sent immediately to the Mining Association and theMiners' Federation respectively.(iii)A draft letter to the mining association.The Lord Privy Seal made a statement to theCabinet in which he emphasised the political difficulties which would be encountered incarrying the proposed policy through parliament and the criticisms to which the proposals wouldbe exposed.The President of the Board of Trade made avery full statement in regard to the proposals. -The Cabinet then examined the proposals para-graph by paragraph.The discussion focussed in the main upon theproposals relating to regulation of price andto the power to grant financial assistance tothe export trade, or other sections of the coal trade, by means of a levy upon output.xNOTE. This document had only been completed and circulated very late on the previous evening. It is understood that some members of the Cabinet had received acopy marked "Revise", containing somenecessary verbal alterations, but this had not been distributed to all members,and these Conclusions refer to theoriginal copy and not to the revise. While recognising that theses-proposals, and moreparticularly the latter, would he severely criticised, the Cabinet, after anxious considera-tion, accepted the view that they were an essential part of the policy and that their omission would render it impossible to oarry out that policy by which alone the Government * s pledges in regardto the reduction of hours could be implemented.While regretting that the great urgency laf thequestion compelled them to reach decisions without an opportunity of knowing the Prime Minister'views on these questions, the Cabinet agreed (a) To approve the proposals in relationto the Coal Industry under discussion between the Government, the mining association and the Miners1 Federation,attached to Paper CP.-292 (29),subject to the following amendments of detail:-Ci) Paragraph II: for "nationalisation of coal royalties" put "Stateacquisition of coal royalties".(ii) Under the heading "Regulation of output", paragraph (cj on page 3,for the words "financial assist-es-nce to the export trade or"put "financial assistance to export coal or".(b) In giving their approval to the above,to take note that the State acquisition,of coal royalties had been includedin order to set forth the policy as awhole, but that this was a matter forthe Government and not for discussionwith the Mining Association or the miners Federation.(c) To invite the attention of the Presi-dent of the Board of Trade to thecomplete survey of all the coalfieldsin this country which has been carriedout by the Fuel Research Commission on instructions from the Lord Presidentof the Council In 1924.(d) To approve the draft reply to Mr Cookattached to CP.-292 (29), subject tothe following amendments:-(l) The first paragraph to ocncludewith some"such phrase as thefollowing: - The Cabinet had before them an InterimReport (Paper CP 295 (29)) by the industrial transference Committee set up at the previous meeting of the Cabinet. In this Report it was stated that the Committee were unanimously ofopinion that the policy of industrial transferenceis necessary and should, in some amended form,be continued. The Committee inclined to theview -(i) That as far as possible mentransferred from depressed areas should be employed on national schemes of work.(ii) In the case of Local authorities with an average rate of unemploy-ment of from 6 to 10 per cent.,the percentage of transferred men should not be rigidly fixed as acondition for the receipt of agrant.(iil) The percentage of transferredmen to be employed on LocalAuthorities' schemes in suchcases should be a matter for negotiation with the LocalAuthority concerned havingregard to local conditions, witha view to introducing a greater degreeof elasticity into the scheme.The Committee stated, however, that this mustnot be regarded as their final views, and before reaching definite conclusions asked -(a) That the Lord Privy Seal.shouldbe added to the Committee; and(b) That the Committee should haveclear directions as to whetheror not it is to consider thegeneral policy of the Governmenton schemes for providing employment.The Cabinet agreed (l) That the Lord Privy Seal should beadded to the Committee.(2) That their intention in appointingthe Committee had been to limit its terms of reference solely to thequestion of Industrial Transference, but that If, after the Ooiflmlt-t.eehad completed their inquiry onthis subject, the Lord Privy Sealjoined with his colleagues in recommending, further investigation of the question in connection with national schemes for Unemployment,they should be authorised to pursue their inquiry into such matters. ilDOWSIfphans'Im old ageloNTBlBUTOBYfeflsioNs BILL.I previous Reference:I cabinet 381(29), Con-I elusion 9.)4. The Home Secretary, as a matter of urgency,raised the question of the abolition of capital punishment, which was to be discussed in theHouse of Commons the same afternoon.The Cabinet agreed with the view of theHome Secretary that he should adopt a sympatheticattitude towards a Debate on this question andintimate that the Government would be glad to learn the views of the House of Commons. TheHome Secretary should be authorised to announce,if necessary, that if the view of the House was clearly in favour of a change an Inquiry shouldbe initiated.-8- TNG OP 6.
